thread.title: Despite colorful protest, demolition resumes on old Hawthorne Boulevard house
thread.title_full: Despite colorful protest, demolition resumes on old Hawthorne Boulevard house | OregonLive.com

author: Stuart Tomlinson | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Despite colorful protest, demolition resumes on old Hawthorne Boulevard house
text:
Workers begin tearing down Hawthorne Boulevard home at center of demolition protest A man who was squatting in a large white house on Hawthorne Boulevard decided on Thursday to try and prevent its demolition by climbing on to the roof in protest. He later came down on his own. Demolition of the house to make way for a 30-unit apartment complex resumed Friday.
Workers resumed demolishing the stately, if care-worn, house at 3423 S.E. Hawthorne Blvd. on Friday morning, a day after a squatter climbed on the home's roof to prevent its demise.
The 2,664-square-foot house, which has been vacant since being sold for $900,000 in July, was built in 1909, but had clearly seen better days. When it's gone, developers plan to build a five-story, 30-unit apartment complex on the site. The plans call for on-site bicycle parking, but no on-site car parking.
The owner is listed as Victor Suk Takla of Portland and the contractor is MCH Construction of Beaverton, according to City of Portland permits issued in August.
Rather than a protest about developers removing historic or large trees to make way for new homes or apartments -- like happened twice in Southeast Portland in late September -- this protest was about what some people perceive as the wholesale death and destruction of old Portland.
Â» Portland home demolitions: Where do they happen?
According to its website, the group Stop Demolishing Portland seeks to preserve Portland's "affordable, historic and vintage housing stock" by petition, by talking with developer and by demonstrations.
The 26-year-old man's protest drew a large crowd to the already busy Hawthorne Boulevard street scene. Three men were arrested for supporting the man's protest.
Robert L. West, 50, Scotty L. Atkins, 45, and Pedro Sanchez Jr., 53, were all booked into the Justice Center Jail on accusations of second-degree disorderly conduct. Atkins and Sanchez were also accused of interfering with a police officer. Sanchez also had an outstanding warrant for an unrelated incident.
A fourth man -- 36-year-old Brad Mathew Whisler -- was arrested Thursday on accusations of first-degree criminal mischief for allegedly damaging a police car with a key, police said.
The unidentified house-sitter rappelled down from the roof at about 9:30 p.m. Thursday. The property owner decided not to press charges against him, police said.
At first light Friday -- as security guards kept watch and removed fencing erected Thursday -- workers began knocking down the house at the rear with a small tracked excavator.
As the machine's bucket and claws chomped away, pulling away shredded carpet, lathe and plaster and water pipes, workers gathered salvageable metal and piled it in the home's small backyard.
Just over the fence to the north, neighbor Andrea Strauss said other than some late night screaming emanating from the house during the summer, she was unaware that squatters had been living there.
She was also unaware that a young man from Brazil was found dead in the home during the hot summer months. At the request of the man's family, the Multnomah County Medical Examiner's Office will not release the man's name or cause of death. No foul play was involved, police said.
"I think it's really sad they're tearing it down," Strauss said. "It's a bad choice. I think it's terrible that they would tear down a historical building for a brand new apartment up; it's very out-of-character for Hawthorne."
Strauss said that adding many more people to the neighborhood is going to also make parking harder, and that "it's already tough to park on our street."
On Thursday, another neighbor, Andrew Waltz, said he posted a photograph of the house sitter on Facebook at about 12:30 p.m., shortly after the man climbed up. He said the city appeared to be too lax in allowing developers to tear down homes, but was not sad to see the squatters go.
"These are out-of-towners who care very little about the integrity of the neighborhood," said Waltz, 31. "They just want to keep their squat spot."
-- Stuart Tomlinson
stomlinson@oregonian.com
